qas.question: Do glaciers require permanent snow or only temporary coverage?
Between which north latitudes are glaciers not found?
Between which latitudes to mountains tend to have permanent snow?
Why do mountains between 19N and 19S tend to have snow?

plausible_answers.text: degree of slope on the land, amount of snowfall and the winds.

qas.question: What affects the perminant ice layer needed for glaciers to form?
What can be found in every country from 20 degrees to 27 degess north and south of the equator?
At what lattitudes does the Hadley circulation rais percipitation?
At what latitudes does low percipitation lead to permanent snow?

context: The <a0_0>permanent snow cover<a0_0/> necessary for glacier formation is affected by factors such as the <b4_0>degree of slope on the land, amount of snowfall and the winds.<b4_0/> <b5_0>Glaciers<b5_0/> can be found in all latitudes except from <a1_0><b6_0>20° to 27° north<a1_0/> and south<b6_0/> of the equator where the presence of the descending limb of the Hadley circulation lowers precipitation so much that with high insolation snow lines reach above 6,500 m (21,330 ft). Between <a2_0><b7_0>19˚N and 19˚S<a2_0/>,<b7_0/> however, <a3_0>precipitation is higher<a3_0/> and the mountains above 5,000 m (16,400 ft) usually have permanent snow.
